Literature Review: Conspiracy theories, defined as explanations for events or phenomena that invoke secret plots by powerful groups, have become a focal point of psychological and sociological research due to their prevalence and impact on society. This literature review explores the defining characteristics of conspiracy theories, their predictors, consequences, and modes of communication, drawing on recent scholarly work to provide a comprehensive overview of the field. The study of conspiracy theories has evolved significantly over the past two decades, with researchers identifying key features that distinguish these beliefs from other types of misinformation or skepticism. One such feature is the dualistic nature of conspiracy theories, which often portray the world in terms of a struggle between good and evil forces (Douglas et al., 2019). This characteristic not only facilitates the adoption of conspiracy beliefs but also influences their transmission and the intensity of belief among individuals. Research has identified several predictors of conspiracy belief, including psychological factors such as a predisposition towards paranoia and a need for cognitive closure (Swami et al., 2011). Sociodemographic factors, such as education level and political orientation, also play a significant role, with studies indicating that individuals with lower levels of education and those who identify as politically conservative are more likely to endorse conspiracy theories (Uscinski & Parent, 2014). The consequences of conspiracy beliefs are wide-ranging and can have detrimental effects on both individuals and society. For individuals, belief in conspiracy theories has been linked to decreased trust in institutions, increased political cynicism, and a reduced likelihood of engaging in civic activities (Jolley & Douglas, 2014). At the societal level, conspiracy theories can undermine public health efforts, as seen in the reluctance of some individuals to vaccinate their children due to unfounded conspiracy theories about vaccine safety (Lewandowsky et al., 2013). The communication of conspiracy theories has been facilitated by the rise of social media, which allows for the rapid dissemination of these beliefs to a wide audience. Research has shown that conspiracy theories are more likely to be shared on social media platforms than factual information, due in part to their sensational nature and the emotional responses they elicit (Del Vicario et al., 2016). Despite the progress made in understanding conspiracy theories, there are still significant gaps in the literature. For example, the role of cultural and historical context in shaping conspiracy beliefs has been underexplored, as has the potential for interventions to reduce belief in conspiracy theories (van Prooijen & Douglas, 2017). Furthermore, the majority of research has focused on Western contexts, limiting our understanding of how conspiracy theories operate in different cultural settings (Butter & Knight, 2016). In conclusion, while significant strides have been made in the study of conspiracy theories, there is a need for further research that takes into account the complex interplay of psychological, sociodemographic, and cultural factors that contribute to the adoption, consequences, and communication of these beliefs. A more nuanced understanding of conspiracy theories will be essential for developing effective strategies to mitigate their negative impact on individuals and society.
